Award.AwardTitle: University of Maryland Noyce Scholars Program for Science Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: To meet the acute need for highly qualified science teachers in the Prince George's County Public Schools, the University of Maryland is recruiting and training students majoring in chemistry, physics, biology, and engineering to earn secondary or middle-school teaching certification. Two avenues offer such students opportunities to test their interest in teaching: tutoring in middle school and serving as Learning Assistants (undergraduate teaching assistants) for introductory university science courses. Opportunities for summer internships in Washington-area science agencies or in research on science education are also available. Students availing themselves of these opportunities are then eligible to apply for scholarship support in their junior and senior years of study. A total of between 22 and 25 new teachers are thereby produced. The teacher education program is likewise enhanced through this project. Noyce Scholars take a supplementary seminar introducing them to strategies for successful teaching in high-need schools; they are supported in attending science education conferences or workshops each year; and they have the opportunity for further professional development in teaching English-language learners. Once they have graduated, new teachers continue to be supported in their early years of teaching through regular meetings, mentoring, and coaching visits with an experienced master teacher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nationally, and within the state of Maryland, high-needs schools struggle to attract and retain highly qualified science teachers. In Maryland, the colleges and universities produce too few science teachers to meet demand. The University of Maryland (UM) offers multiple pathways by which undergraduate science majors can pursue careers in high school teaching, and our graduates are eagerly sought by local school districts. The University of Maryland Noyce Scholars Program for Science Teachers (2013-2019) partnered with a local high-needs school district, Prince George’s County Public Schools (PGCPS), to focus on 


  1. increasing the number of underrepresented minority students and the number of total students graduating from our science teacher certification programs;

  2. increasing the number of those graduates, both total and underrepresented, who teach in PGCPS and other high-needs schools and districts;

  3. producing excellent teachers of students in high-needs schools.


To do so, our program employed two main strategies. First, it provided early teaching-related opportunities for freshman and sophomore STEM majors including summer internships, undergraduate teaching assistantships (TAs) and tutor positions in local schools. These early experiences were intended to allow STEM majors to “dip their toes” into teaching, in hopes of recruiting them into a teacher certification pathway. Second, the program offered scholarships to UMD STEM students accepted into one of our science teacher certification programs. 

The tutoring program supported dozens of science majors from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds to work in local high-needs middle schools and high schools in Prince George’s County. Some tutors worked with students after school; others served as in­-class assistants, helping to facilitate small­ group discussions and/or working with individual students. For the summer interns, work sites included the UM Physics Education and Biology Education Research Groups, the UM Earth and Space Science Lab, Montgomery County Public Schools, the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration, and the American Physical Society. Undergraduate teaching assistants worked to support student learning in undergraduate STEM courses. Some of the students participating in these experiences went on to become Noyce Scholars, the students receiving a scholarship to support their progress toward becoming certified science teachers..

Ultimately, the program supported 18 Noyce scholars, 6 of whom came from racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM and 8 of whom taught in shortage areas such as chemistry and physics. All of the Noyce Scholars who graduated from our program are teaching in high-needs school districts. Classroom observations and interviews with supervisors suggest they are very good novice teachers.

 An unplanned success of the program was providing recruitment strategies for a new undergraduate STEM education program on campus, called Terrapin Teachers.  Terrapin Teachers is a replication of UTeach, a national model of STEM teacher preparation developed at the University of Texas. Since its inception in 2014, Terrapin Teachers has become the main source of University of Maryland students seeking to become science teachers.  In the years 2009-2014, the University of Maryland produced an average of 7 certified science teachers per year. In the years 2015-2020, we produced an average of 10 students per year, and the numbers are rising. We attribute this in part to the synergy between the Noyce program and Terrapin Teachers.
